job_title: Route Sales Representative in Colorado Springs, CO
pros:
Paid weekly
Meet lots of people
4 day work week 
That’s it!
cons: If you enjoy having to fight to be paid and have it corrected then this is the place for you! I worked for the company from May of 2021 to November of 2021 and in those few months they messed my pay up a total of 6 times it became so ridiculous that I quit bringing it up to them. Management failed their employees in so many ways from support to gossiping about other employees it was just pathetic they couldn’t even do what they were supposed to. Such as fixing safety issues like broken tucks and carts and lifts instead they will joke about it. The hours they expect out of you in the four days you work are unreal it never just a 40 hour week. Any hours over 40 are only 6.5 not time and a half it’s in there pay plan make sure you read. If you think HR will help you with these issues think again HR only cares about your vaccinations status. Rules are constantly changing and you are expected to know and keep up with them even if your management dose not inform you. Be prepared to have to explain to customers on a regular basis why you are out of items and they are still being charged for them and that this is all in their agreement that they will be held to. Overall this company will sell you a big picture of a four day work week, great weekly pay, and team work non of this exist here. Instead be prepared for long days no help poor management and begging for your pay to be corrected and fighting for time off and being told even if a family member is dying your job is more important. I would not recommend this place in fact I would recommend you run and not look back.

review_title: Could have been a great place to work..
pros: 401k/benefits, 3 day weekends, paid weekly, time flies on route
cons:
Hours...4 day weeks are the sole reason many SSR's I knew stayed for as long as they did. Sounds great, unless of course your regularly working 12 hour days along with starting your day at 5:30 am. It was not unheard of to get done with work around 6-7pm. 

Truck Safety...most of the SSR box trucks had no heat or AC and there was not a plan to fix them that I had ever heard. If it was in the 90's outside it was 100 in the truck and I honestly don't know how nobody has dropped dead in a truck. 

Shorts...were not permitted ever. Only pants even in the dead of summer. This was simply because leadership is old school and didn't think it very business like to walk into office buildings with shorts on. I'll never understand how that is better than drenched from head to toe in sweat or giving customers sweat covered invoices.

Overtime...because you are an hourly/commission based employee Cintas manages to get away with not paying any real overtime. Their explanation is that if you are working more hours your route is bringing in more revenue and your commissions are higher...this is not always the case

Ethical issues/being short product...SSR's being shorted pay, commissions not being paid, commission plans being changed at random by management. Inventory ordering was regularly pushed off until the beginning of the month. It was a very common to not have product for customers and we were always short soap, chemicals, and paper products. Oftentimes you would finish a route and have to drop by again with products but it was always a headache to walk into accounts without product. Management would lie to SSR's about product eta on a regular basis.

cons:
- The "Culture" is a nightmare bordering the realm of cultish. Everyone feels the need to publicly announce how great the culture is on Linkedin yet no one looks out for anyone but themselves and pretty much everyone's miserable. Frequent public displays of loyalty are usually indicative of a fear based culture (which Cintas definitely is).

- Management is extremely manipulative and tries to convince its people that pay cuts are actually great opportunities to make more money. They have ways to make sure that your commissions aren't paid out in full and they try to brainwash you into believing your part of an elite team as this allows them to convince you to work harder for less pay.

- Management will bring in new sales people and start making a big deal out of them in public for no reason. Their intention is to make the other sales reps competitive and work harder, yet the new reps are then left to fend off the wolves without any protection. Just an overall terrible environment to work in as you will be constantly exposed Machiavellian and psychopathic manipulation tactics as well as small minded, insecure people.

review_title: Great company, great benefits, but be a people person
pros:
Once you learn every aspect of your job, it’s a very easy flowing day. You know what to do, get to know the products and services you provide no matter what your job is, prioritize correctly, & be a hard worker, your day is fairly easy. 

I wasn’t ever trained on all the services that were provided & thrown into customer service. You need to understand every part of that company & also the partners you work with. Don’t only know their job title, know everything that they do on a daily basis. That way when a problem arises that’s not in your department, you know exactly who to send it to or it might just be disregarded.

They have “QGG’s” showing you how to do everything! Along with a website of all Cintas workers where people can ask questions & you can read the solutions, instead of running to your manager every time. You have all the tools at your disposal. If you learn every aspect of every department as much as you can & get along with everyone, you won’t go to work everyday hating life. If you’re not that type of person, it likely isn’t for you. Working together is the best priority in anything in life.
cons:
I have no cons with the actual company. But the con lies with I who the company has hired. 

 You will need to get along with everyone to do your job correctly. Sometimes even when you try, other partners just won’t like you no matter what you do. When you send them work, it never gets done & that is on you even if it’s not in your job description. So make sure the company has a good work flow between all the partners in the office. If there’s a lot of drama or people talking, it’s likely a toxic environment to be in. It has nothing to do with the company though, they treat everyone well & have great benefits. It just depends on the partners. So really I have no cons with the company. Just make sure you have the proper training & also learn how to train yourself.

pros: Benefits-Cintas has a great benefits package they offer.
cons: Make sure you save documentation correspondence you receive from HR. Because they will lie for the company to ensure you don’t get paid unemployment benefits. So it doesn’t come from the company. If any work related accident happens, ensure you get the proper video, correspondence of any to cover yourself. Because they will make sure they try and protect the company!

Managers all got each other hired.

Plant management holds grudges on employees and refuses to do their yearly review.
1-2 hours sitting around waiting to check out

The hiring process can take up to 6 months
Instead of properly training, you get rushed through so they can send you out. It was easier to yell at you for not knowing your job than actually teaching you how to do your job properly.
My location didn't do inventory management so customers would be missing mats, towels, or uniforms for weeks to months. When you credit the account, you would get "talked to" because they don't like credits.
Any plan to save money, time, and manage inventory was met with "we just don't do things like that"
Zero oversight on service. Instead of auditing their load sheet drivers take 100% of their load and bring back over half. With the no inventory management thing this leads to massive shortages.
Management meets with angry customers to set a plan to fix the issue. Service is expected to do their part but they are left hanging when management won't do their tasks.

review_title: Cintas great if you plan to stay
job_title: Management Trainee in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Great investment into personal and professional development
cons: Chatty, gossip, office politics is cumbersome

pros: The car package consisted of: $365, $50 cell phone allowance, $54 monthly maintenance and gas card. This was a pro because you will put in 25-45k miles per year on your personal vehicle.
cons:
Where do I start? Company preaches their “culture”. That Spartan mentality they claim and boast about. However, in my experience each location is far from it. This is the boys club. If you fit in, great, if you don’t.. you’ll be gone soon. 

The amount of stress to get a GOOD sale is decent,  but the stress of dealing with it afterwards is ridiculous. 

The service team at my location was EXTREMELY inefficient and disconnected with their responsibility. It was like having to fight fires, all day every day on their behalf. Customers will hate you after they realize how you locked them into a contract for 5 years and the verbiage you used was “service agreement”. You told them they could complain and get out but the service team is telling them, “Nope, it’s a contract for 5 years, pay the remaining weeks or we’ll take you to court. I don’t care if you’re a mom and pop shop, we’ll sue you.” 

You’re expected to come into the office and make 240 calls per week at least to set a minimum of 16-20 appointments and then do  50 new onsite visits (cold calls) per week around those appointments. The work is not hard if you love sales, but their expectations are a little ridiculous. If you don’t bring in their undefined weekly sales expectation, they’re quick to put reps on PIPs.  On top of those visits and appointments, you also have to go load up stuff that your service team forgot, uniforms they left behind, or other items they needed. Oh and if you’re unable to help them out, too bad, the customer will still get charged and they hope they don’t notice.

Reps are sold on the idea of making 6 figures quick, which can be achieved but there are a lot of uncontrollable aspects to get there like: lack of inventory, location and competition. They claim to be better but in reality they’re the same thing. You can’t possibly expect the same production from someone who is in a big city with more opportunities than someone in a rural area where there isn’t a huge need.

I don’t regret working here because it taught me to persevere against so many different things but I would never return to that industry. It didn’t bring me satisfaction even though I produced good numbers, I never felt like I accomplished a good thing and I was always stressed out on Sunday evenings thinking of the week ahead.

review_title: Great Company but all they care about are numbers!
pros: The benefits are awesome! Amazing health insurance and 401K. The salary is decent. It is on the low end for outside sales though, so this would be a good job right out of college. They give you a car allowance, pay your gas and cell phone allowance.The team culture is great! Paid time off is generous. You start with 3 weeks PTO. In sales, you can generally take off any day you request which is nice.
cons: All they care about are numbers. Your goals start to go up very quickly and when you’re fully tenured it’s very hard to hit your numbers. Then they are quick to put you on a performance plan. It’s like they want to get rid of you just to hire someone new. They don’t do a good job investing in current employees who are already trained. Your training depends on if you have a good manager. The first manager knew nothing about the division and the second one did. Starting out I needed help and some senior team members were very knowledgeable but then would complain to the manager that I was asking them questions! Then I was told to ask my manager who then had to ask the senior team members for help anyways! The second manger was very knowledgeable, but would micromanage us like crazy and didn’t care about the team and was very selfish. We all quickly learned he only cared about himself and looking good to our director. Thousands of employees were laid off in April. They decided to keep someone brand new on the team! And instead got rid of three fully trained employees. Makes no sense at all! Then they said if you saw the position posted you could apply again. Not sure why they didn’t just furlough vs lay off employees. Definitely disappointed in cintas and how they handled the pandemic. They pay your car insurance which means they control your every move! If you get any sort of a ticket it’s a write up. They want you to always park your car in reverse when in a parking spot. They don’t even allow you to go on your own car insurance if you want to. Overall, this was a very stressful job. And who likes working for a company that doesn’t care about their employees and only the bottom line. You can make decent money with commissions but it’s not even worth it at the end of the day. Also, VERY high turnover 7 people were gone in less than 2 years.

pros: Cintas has a world class sales training program. I've worked for 3 Fortune 500 companies, and I would say this is the best of them all from consistency to success in the field. Benefits are really good, and they do care about the general wellness of their employees on a local level. Resume Building Block. Autonomy, when out of office. Commission can be incredible, and total earnings can be very high for an entry level sales position
cons:
Politics (locally), very sorority & fraternity feel, and I've witnessed sales representatives be terminated and their sales numbers given unequally to specific team members (who weren't top performing) but had favorable personal relationships with the managers. If you don't have a great relationship with your Service Manager's & Drivers (High school, GED, aka they don't care and have high turnover) then you will have deals lost, backed out, delayed and constant headaches because ultimately the decide if your deal runs and you get paid. 

Sell you on how much opportunity there is for new business, without telling you about the MDR position that eats into new business opportunity, and that their 5 year contracts lock in customers for so long the zip codes your given might be 60-70% currently serviced by Cintas. They'll tell you how many businesses there are in your zip codes, but leave forget to leave out financial institutions (banks, cap mgmt firms), lawyers, obvious businesses that don't need uniforms or tp or paper towels...
Biggest competition is internally. FS & Uniform reps are desperate weekly to post numbers so they will self sabotage each other and the company ultimately by getting pinned against one another with local prospects who have both reps calling on them at the same time. Ultimately, they might use Cintas reps to drive cost as low as possible to sign with competitor

Your product is unreasonably high with crazy margins built in, which ultimately are entirely to expensive for majority of their customers to maintain throughout the duration of the contract, and the biggest customers who have the most money, you're taught to give them the lowest cost to get the deal done quick (which pays you the least commission, but they get near the same profits).

Aggressive sales management, if you don't post a weekly number close to expectation, you're already under the microscope. Also drives you to work unreasonable hours to hit quota, which makes the overall pay watered down considering the hours worked, and stress involved.

review_title: My Mental Health Drastically Improved After Leaving this Company
pros:
Health Benefits
PTO
The brand is looked at positively by outsiders
cons:
Location: If inhaling asbestos and working in an industrial town 20 miles from Chicago with no option of public transport sounds good, then this is the place for you. (Winters are fun)
Management: Monkeys in suits would be a better option. The atmosphere is authoritarian with no team dynamics or modern leadership (good luck having an opinion or feedback taken seriously). CEO is an out-of-touch moron, only in a position because of nepotism.
Other benefits: Outdated, don't even bring up work from home, it only took a pandemic to get them to move from this policy. No flexible hours, expensive cafeteria, bare minimum holidays, no summer hours, team/company events are a joke. Ridiculous business professional dress code (tie or jacket) when manual labor in the warehouse is sometimes a requirement for desk employees
Facilities: One word: Gray. Dusty cubicles. Attached to a loud warehouse. Nothing gets you more depressed than walking into this place. Everything is outdated including the technology. 
Internal Growth: Cintas loves to tout how they promote from within. This is untrue, you will see new faces in the office constantly (mainly because of high turnover) and instead of promoting a long-term employee, they hire from outside.
Culture: Work/life balance is non-existent. There is the classic "live to work" instead of "work to live" mindest. Probably because the majority of people working here are old. The company struggles to retain anyone 40 and under despite having a program dedicated to recruiting college students.

review_title: Too many captains, not enough crew.
pros:
Schedule: 4 on, 3 off with weekends off.
Commissions: If you like commissions, they got them. Its most of your pay, so get ready to sell sell sell.
Insurance: I liked the insurance. For me and my partner I think it was about 30 bucks for coverage. Dental and health.
cons:
Training: You get a month, if you are lucky, and then you are out on your own. 
Stress: Your shifts can vary between 9-14 hours depending on your performance. If you are lost, that's going to affect your day drastically. If you know what you're doing, your day is gonna be easy. However, regardless of how good you are at your job, you're going to have accounts that just drag your day, and there is nothing you can do about it. Example: They require you to go to 10 buildings in one plaza vs 1 drop off.
Heat: If you're in AZ, the truck can reach temperatures up to 120, so get ready to sweat from the moment you come in, until the moment you leave. Plus all the heavy lifting and working outside sorting laundry in the blazing sun. Not to mention the trucks might die on you and there goes your whole day waiting for someone to come out and trade you trucks so you can finish your route. 
COVID19: Please be advised that you will be dealing with people's dirty laundry, and retrieving dirty mats off the floor. Both of these interactions put you in direct line of this virus, so if you cannot handle that, I would not even apply because all you get is some flimsy gloves and the mask that everyone wears. Sanitation supplies are limited and they struggled to supply us with them during the ordeal.

job_title: Market Development Representative in Duluth, MN
pros:
As a company...
This company moves people that bring results up the ladder. 
They are proffessional and have a unique culture that pushes quality and urgency. Making raving fans of their customers is top priority. 
They truly strive to stand behind their product. 
Team mentality, if you need help reach out.
Constantly striving to improve the system.
Everyone works Hard!
Fantastic people and managers.
Fast growing industry.
I honestly really enjoyed the people and culture.
cons:
Not all of these are cons necessarily cons, however they could be depending on perspective.

They expect alot. I frequently recieved emails and phone calls after hours and on weekends. This isn't a bad thing if you just silence your phone. 

Results are the bottom line, if its not for you, you will figure it out soon enough.

Very rapid environment.

Not as much structure as alot of companies their size.

You need to be able to adapt without warning and run with it.

In all honesty, the biggest con is that not everyone they hire embodies the pros. They do their best to weed out the nonsense, however it's a big company so it exists. That goes for any company of this size. Its a shame that some locations get less attention than others, however, I have confidence that will change with time. I would work for Cintas again without thinking twice.
